sections.html:
Zone 2 • Experiments

Magnet Placement Experiments

Step-by-Step Protocols to Test Orientation Effects With Real Controls

If someone claims magnetics changes water, the correct response is: "Which placement? What polarity? What distance? Still or flowing?"

This page gives you the standards to test and compare results globally.

Definition

Magnet placement experiments test whether field position, polarity and distance create repeatable changes in water fingerprints compared to a baseline under identical conditions.

Equipment & Minimum Kit

Minimum Kit

  • 2–4 identical glass containers
  • Thermometer
  • EC/TDS meter
  • ORP meter
  • pH meter/strips
  • Turbidity tube
  • 1–2 magnets (same size)
Get The Kit

Recommended Upgrade

  • Known magnet strength (Gauss)
  • Ruler/spacer blocks (fix distance)
  • Labels & permanent marker
  • Light exposure control box

Variables You MUST Fix

Golden Rule: One change at a time.

  • 1. Water source
  • 2. Volume (mL)
  • 3. Container Material
  • 4. Room conditions
  • 5. Open vs Closed
  • 6. Magnet type
  • 7. Distance (mm)
  • 8. Duration
  • 9. Time Points
Download Log Sheet

Standard Time Points

T0 (Setup) • T30 (30m) • T2h (2 Hours) • T24h (24 Hours)

Measure full fingerprint at every point: Temp, EC, ORP, pH, Turbidity.

Protocol A: Still Water / Side Placement

Goal: Test Field Exposure (Starter)

Setup: A = Control (No magnet). B = Magnet at side.

Placement: Fixed spacer distance (e.g. 10mm). Mark polarity.

Measure: All time points.

Tests exposure without flow confounders.

Protocol B: Two-Sided Field (N↔S)

Goal: Strong Orientation Test

Setup: A = Control. B = Magnet pair opposite sides.

Placement: N facing water one side, S facing water other side. Aligned height.

Creates clear directional field across volume.

Protocol C: Polarity Flip (N vs S)

Goal: Does Polarity Matter?

Setup: A = Control. B = N facing. C = S facing.

Interpretation: Only count if B and C diverge consistently.

Protocol E: Flow-Through (Advanced)

Warning: Flow Changes Gases

Setup: A = Flow control (tubing, no magnet). B = Flow + magnet.

Control: You must match flow pattern exactly. Flow alters ORP via aeration.

Vortex/Flow Logic

Results Interpretation

Meaningful Result

  • Repeatable directional change across 3 runs.
  • Consistent divergence from control.
  • Not explained by temp diffs.

Noise / Artifact

  • Single number shift.
  • Inconsistent flipping.
  • Correlates with temperature drift.

Mantra: Patterns over numbers.

Submit Your Data

Mandatory fields: Location, Source, Container, Magnet Type, Polarity, Distance, Duration, Temp + Fingerprints.

Upload to Citizen Science Hub

items.question: What magnets should I use?
items.answer: Use consistent magnets (same type/size). Neodymium is common for repeatability, but consistency matters more than strength.

items.question: Do I need to know polarity?
items.answer: It helps for Protocol C, but you can run side-placement and distance tests without it.

items.question: Why is temperature so important?
items.answer: Temperature shifts can change ORP and pH readings and can mimic "effects."

items.question: Still water or flowing water first?
items.answer: Still water first—flow introduces too many confounders.

items.question: How many repeats are enough?
items.answer: Minimum 3 repeats on different days for each protocol.
